data.name: Get/Set bitwise flags using a single integer
data.description:
Binary numbers can be used to store a bunch of data in a single `integer` column.
For example, if you have multiple ways to broadcast a notification and a user can say which channels they want to receive a notification through.

Let's say your channels are `email`, `sms`, `app`, `web`, and `phone`.
You'd normally need 5 different boolean columns to track which channels the user wants. However, we can use binary to store all of these in a single field.

Keeping the channels in order, using the first letter to identify them, you end up with `esawp`. Mapping that to binary, you can have `1` represent `true` and `0` represent `false`.

```
esawp
10010
```

Looking at the above, we see a 1 for e and w, meaning the user wants `email` and `web` notifications, but no other ones.
Starting from the right, each bit is 2x the previous bit starting with 1.

```
00001 == 1
00010 == 2
00100 == 4
01000 == 8
10000 == 16
etc...
```

When you have multiple bits, you just count them up:

```
esawp
10010 == [16 + 0 + 0 + 2 + 0] == 18
```

Using your newfound knowledge of binary, write a getter and setter for a user's notifications.

The input `channels` will be a base 10 number representing the starting notification preferences (18 == `email` and `web`)

The input `flag` will always be a power of 2, representing a single notification type value. (1 being phone, 2 == web, 16 == email, etc)

`get` - return true/false based on whether the flag is present in the given channels.

`add` - return a new base 10 number with the new flag added to the given channels list.

`remove` - return a new base 10 number with the new flag removed from the given channels list.

Hint: Although you can solve these without, try to use bitwise operations in all three methods!
